bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 16, 1947

div1.p: Kean discusses Wallace Forbes, a yellow fever volunteer who disappeared November 24, 1926 while in the service. He suggests that Forbes' medal be given to his sister.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 16, 1947

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
16 Sept. '47

div1.p:
In the Wash. Post of last
Saturday was what was to me
a very interesting article-
It told the story of Wallace W.
Forbes whose name is on the
yellow fever Roll of Honor, but
who disappeared Nov. 24, 1926
while in the service at San Francisco
and has never reappeared to claim
his gold medal or draw his pen-
sion- I always regarded him as a
deserter, but when I was preparing the
Yellow Fever Roll of Honor in the account
of his yellow fever attack I put in “He was
honorably discharged from the Army four
years later” This was perfectly true and
2
that was the end as far as the Medical
Service was concerned- But in the
Adjutant General's record of his service
which is a very condensed statement of
service is shown a reenlist in the line
of the Army in 1916 and his service as Sergt
to Nov 24, 1926- There is no statement
as to why he left the service for his
current enlistment had not expired-
This article was written from data
furnished apparently by the F B I says
that the F B I has been working on
the case for 17 years and have never
been able to find a trace of him or
any clue as to what became of him-
He was carried for a while as A O W L
but there was no reason to suppose
that he was a deserter as he was a
Sergeant in good standing with no
Known cause for desertion- He could
doubtless have gotten an honorable
discharge if he had asked for it.
The article says that the officers of his
3
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Regiment (Co. I, 30th Infantry) beleived
that he had been made away with
but there was no reason apparent
why he should have been attacked.
But some disposition had to be made
of his gold medal and the pension
has accumulated since the award
28 Feb. 1929 to about $30,000 dollars-
So F. B. I recommends that he be
considered as dead and that his
medal be given to a sister who is
alive and married- The pension
money goes back into the U. S. Treasury
as he probably was dead at the time
that it was graduated-

I cut the article out to send to you
but when I came to do so it had
disappeared and I have not been
able to find it- Here are the facts
It you want the article I can probably
get a copy from the Wash. Post

It seems to me a long time since I
have had news of you- I have
reason often to think of you at
5 oclock- Where did you go in the
very hot weather which you had
in Minn last month?

closer.seg:
P.S.
Do not assume from my envelope
that I am sick at Walter Reed Hosp.
The fact is that I am out of enve-
lopes and Peru Indiana is slow
in coming to my rescue.
